reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s argument that many bounded, separately-aggregating views are “fussy” because even an astronomically tiny fraction of bads can prevent a mostly-great future. This is a real sub-argument in Section 3.3, but it’s only one route to the paper’s broader “no easy eutopia” conclusion (the paper also argues from unbounded linearity, approximate linearity of many bounded views, fat-tailed value-efficiency, and multi-factor fragility), so centrality is moderate rather than high. The critique’s core point—appealing to dilution/ratio intuitions to cast separately-aggregating bounded views as implausible—is relevant, but it mostly asserts an intuition/reductio rather than engaging the paper’s specific structural claim (bounded transforms applied separately + enormous scale makes tiny proportions morally decisive). It also somewhat mischaracterizes the paper as assuming bads ‘cancel regardless of ratio’ and as labeling such futures ‘worse than extinction’/a ‘moral catastrophe’; the paper’s key claim is primarily about failing to reach the >0.5 “mostly-great” threshold (not necessarily below 0). Hence limited refutational strength but decent partial correctness. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and has little dead weight.
title: Bounded views that ignore good-to-bad ratios lead to absurd conclusions
